articles.headline: A Bit More Ethanol in the Gas Tank
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency’s new rules would allow a 15 percent ethanol blend for vehicles manufactured since 2007.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency’s new rules would allow a 15 percent ethanol blend for vehicles manufactured since 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration made a gesture of support for the ethanol industry on Wednesday, with a declaration by the Environmental Protection Agency that gasoline retailers can sell fuel blends containing up to 15 percent ethanol for use in late-model cars.

articles.headline: Financier Is Said to Accept a Ban in Pension Case
articles.snippet: Steven Rattner, who oversaw the Obama administration’s auto-industry overhaul, will accept a ban from the securities industry and pay a fine of more than $5 million, a person with knowledge of the talks said.
articles.abstract: Steven Rattner, who oversaw the Obama administration’s auto-industry overhaul, will accept a ban from the securities industry and pay a fine of more than $5 million, a person with knowledge of the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Rattner, who oversaw the Obama administration’s overhaul of the auto industry, for months resisted a settlement with regulators over his role in New York pension fund kickbacks because he did not want to be banned from the securities industry.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Neglected Gadgets on Stage
articles.snippet: There are several never-reviewed gizmos stuffed in the virtual closet. Let’s look at them now.
articles.abstract: There are several never-reviewed gizmos stuffed in the virtual closet. Let’s look at them now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, this column is about electronics, or software, or tech culture.

articles.headline: Earth Is Parched Where Syrian Farms Thrived
articles.snippet: Ancient irrigation systems have collapsed and villages have been abandoned in the Fertile Crescent.
articles.abstract: Ancient irrigation systems have collapsed and villages have been abandoned in the Fertile Crescent.
articles.lead_paragraph: AR RAQQAH, Syria  The farmlands spreading north and east of this Euphrates River town were once the breadbasket of the region, a vast expanse of golden wheat fields and bucolic sheep herds.

articles.headline: Defying Predictions, Miners Kept Healthy
articles.snippet: Many miners came bounding out of their rescue capsule, testimony to their diet and organization underground.
articles.abstract: Many miners came bounding out of their rescue capsule, testimony to their diet and organization underground.
articles.lead_paragraph: Defying grim predictions about how they would fare after two months trapped underground, many of the Chilean miners came bounding out of their rescue capsule on Wednesday as pictures of energy and health, able not only to walk, but, in one case, to leap around, hug everyone in sight and lead cheers.

articles.headline: Chase Acts to Broaden Foreclosure Reviews
articles.snippet: The bank backed away from an industry-owned registration system that oversees millions of home loans.
articles.abstract: The bank backed away from an industry-owned registration system that oversees millions of home loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the uproar over questionable conduct by mortgage lenders intensified Wednesday, one of the nation’s largest banks distanced itself from a controversial, industry-owned registration system that oversees millions of home loans.

articles.headline: Bankers Ignored Signs of Trouble on Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The foreclosure chaos, caused by disorganization and inexperienced employees, came as no surprise to insiders.
articles.abstract: The foreclosure chaos, caused by disorganization and inexperienced employees, came as no surprise to insiders.
articles.lead_paragraph: At JPMorgan Chase & Company, they were derided as “Burger King kids” — walk-in hires who were so inexperienced they barely knew what a mortgage was.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: U.S. Aids Taliban to Attend Talks on Making Peace
articles.snippet: The U.S. effort to support preliminary talks with the Karzai government might reflect pessimism that the buildup of American forces will defeat the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The U.S. effort to support preliminary talks with the Karzai government might reflect pessimism that the buildup of American forces will defeat the Taliban.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: U.S. to Let Insurers Raise Fees for Sick Children
articles.snippet: The Obama administration said insurers could charge more for children with medical issues, if states allowed it.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration said insurers could charge more for children with medical issues, if states allowed it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, aiming to encourage health insurance companies to offer child-only policies, said Wednesday that they could charge higher premiums for coverage of children with serious medical problems, if state law allowed it.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart to Buy More Local Produce
articles.snippet: With the focus on sustainable agriculture, the retail giant is trying to improve efficiency among suppliers.
articles.abstract: With the focus on sustainable agriculture, the retail giant is trying to improve efficiency among suppliers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The local-and-sustainable food movement has spread to the nation’s largest retailer.
